annotation.text:
INTERVIEWER: Mr.
Houser, all your papers
say it's [? Isaak ?] Houser.
Should we--

ERIC HOUSER: Isaak
Houser, I will say this.

INTERVIEWER: Should you--
should we introduce you as Isaak
Houser, or--
ERIC HOUSER: Well, you can--

I say here my-- my Jewish
name was Isaak Houser--
INTERVIEWER: OK.
Fine.
OK.
ERIC HOUSER: [INAUDIBLE].
INTERVIEWER: OK.
ERIC HOUSER: Whatever--
INTERVIEWER: OK.
ERIC HOUSER: OK?

INTERVIEWER: Yes,
this is Eric Houser.
Um, And today is 29th of April.

And if you would like
to begin, Mr. Houser.

And perhaps you can tell us a
little bit of your childhood
and your hometown.
ERIC HOUSER: Thank you, ma'am.
My name is Eric Houser.
My Jewish name is Isaak Houser--
actually, Itzhak Houser.

I was born in a town of Grodek
It's a very old town in Poland,

which goes back
to the year 1300,

from the time of princes
who were named Jagiełło.

The Americans
called them Jogaila.

My grandfather was the president
of the Jewish community
in this town.

It was a very old town with
a very old Jewish population
and a very old cemetery.
I went there to high school.
It was a Catholic high school.

But my grandfather
was the president
of the Jewish community.

As such, he had enough
influence to place me

in the Catholic high
school which I finished.
I was the valedictorian.

And I finished my
studies down there.

And from there, I decided
to study engineering.

They did not accept
Jewish students

on the Polish
polytechnical school,

so I had to go to
Czechoslovakia.

I finished my
engineering studies

with a master's degree in
electrical and mechanical
engineering in Czechoslovakia.

This diploma was
not acknowledged
by the Polish authorities.

And when I came
back home to Poland,

I had to undergo what is
called nostrification,

which means another exam
in the Polish language.

One could not get work near
Lwów, where my parents were.

My father was a
building contractor.
He built small houses.

He built approximately
300 small houses,

giving out the
mortgages to the people.

At that time, no
bank gave mortgage.
My father gave you mortgages.

And he was a rather-- by
the standards of his time--
well-to-do man.

But I couldn't get a
job in my profession.

A job opened itself
in West Galicia

in a company called
Jakub Szmer and Company.

It was a Jewish man who
accepted me on a try out.
And I stayed with him.

I became assistant
manager of the oil fields.

The chief engineer, his
name was Max Garfunkel.

He was the head of the
engineering department.
I was his assistant.
I worked down there.
I built a house for the company.

And he had 40 or 60 oil
wells, which I [? directed. ?]

I made a few little inventions,
of which I have patents.
Of course, they're all obsolete.

And then the war
started in 1939.

INTERVIEWER: Can we back up
just a little bit without--

I don't want to break up
your train of thought.

But if you would
be good enough to,

perhaps share with us
who was in your family,

a little bit about what
your family life was like.

ERIC HOUSER: Well,
as I said, my father
was a building contractor.
He built houses.

My sister studied
to be an attorney.
And my brother was a accountant.

My sister later owned
a big movie house
in the city of Lemberg.
We all worked very hard.

Although they were
quite well-to-do,
but life was not easy.

One is subjected
continuously to pressures

from the Poles who
couldn't stand it

if a Jew became so wealthy and
who tried all the time, in--

in many, many ways to
ruin my father's business.

For instance, they
built a church,

which was approximately,
I would say,

three miles from our
building establishment.

Yet it was suddenly considered
an offense to the church

that the building
establishment is
close by, where people worked.

We had to fight these
things continuously.

We fought it with
bribes, naturally.

He bribed to the right
and he bribed to the left,

and whatever could be
done to keep alive.

But I wanted to
work as an engineer.

My father very much wanted
me to be in his field.

But first of all, I
was very socialistic.
Let's call it this way.

Most of the youths,
the Jewish youths,

was quite leftist and
socialist at the time.

There seemed to be no hope in
the Polish rule and the way
they treated us.

And I believe it
was Otto Kessler.

Otto Kessler has a famous saying
the red hot sun from the East

will melt down the
injustices of the West.
So one believed in these things.

My father wasn't very
much enthused about it.

He was naturally of
different beliefs.

So I had to leave and
find work for myself.
And I find work--

I found work for
myself in West Galicia.

In the meantime,
my sister married.

She married to an attorney who
later divorced her, emigrated

to Russia, and was promptly
shot by Stalin as a--
as a Polish spy.

My sister bought a big
movie house in Poland.

And my father was
building a huge house--

for Poland, it was a
huge house, a four story
house in the city of Lemberg.

He finished building it
as the first bombs were
falling on Lemberg in 1939.

What is interesting for my
father that he paid his debts.

He was convinced his
work is as good as gold.

While the bombs were
falling, he paid his debts.

Now I worked on this place in
West Galicia, the war came.

The owner said to me you
stay there and watch out

for my business He grabbed
whatever money there was.

He had a bank account in
{?_{?_[NON-ENGLISH SPEECH]._?}._?} And
he managed to escape to America.

I was left with 220 hungry
people, drilling masters,
welders, blacksmiths--

whatever accrue in
such a field this--

boiler man-- and
with no payroll.

There was a little bit of
money left in the bank, which
he left me for small--
I took out this money.

I remember it was
2,500 or so zloty.
And there were 220 of us.

So everybody got 10 zloty,
which is negligible.
It's $2.

But at least it
showed some goodwill.

And that I had
goodwill among these

is the best proof, because
they didn't tear me apart,
these people.
They were mostly Poles.
And that's the way it was.
Then came the order.
I managed to save a man's life.
He was an Ukrainian.
He was a machinist.

And when the war
started, the Poles

believed that all the
Ukrainians are spies.

Ukrainians sided
with the Germans.

Because the
Ukrainians originally

fought against the Poles in
1918 and Poland was built.

So as it was here
with the Japanese

during the war,
Second World War,

the public opinion was
all Ukrainians are spies.
But this was it a nice fellow.
He wasn't a spy.
The war started.

The army came in and they
asked is it an Ukrainian.
And he was pointed out.
So they took him.
Put him against the wall.
His wife gave-- came to me.
I run against.
I grabbed the sergeant.
I told him I vouch--
vouch with my life for this man.
He's a good man.
He never makes any politics.
He's a machinist.

He-- he takes care
of the machines.
So they let him go.

And later on this man
proved helpful to me

during the German
time, a little bit.
But I had a friend in him.
OK.

The war in our parts
[INAUDIBLE] last--
lasted, maybe, for four days.

After four days, the
Polish army crumbled
and kept going to the East.
There was nothing from--

we got orders to
dismantle the oil wells

and to make them
unfunctional, which we did.

We dropped heavy pieces of
iron and steel and tools
into the oil wells.

And then, of course,
we had to run.
Because we know the Germans--
and we dismantled the machinery.

We took off the carburetors
of all the injection pumps,

of all the diesels, and
we hid them somewhere so
the Germans couldn't find them.

It is-- characteristic
that the Germans called me
over the radio by name.

A few days after
I run away, there
was a big radio announcement.

And they said engineer Isaac
Houser should come back.
Everything is forgiven.

They wanted to know where
the machinery is hidden.

But I know that once I show my
face that they will kill me.
So I disregarded it completely.

As I was running away, we
were doing it at night.

Because during the day, the
Germans were everywhere.
I had a car hidden--

an old car which I built
myself practically-- hidden.
I took four people with me.

And we drove on
small country roads.

The country roads in Poland
are built of white stone.
The stone is white.

And when the moon shines in
your face, you can see it.

The trouble was that-- at the
end of the road made a sharp 90

degree bent and
there was a river.
And I didn't know this.
And I didn't notice it.

Because the river and
the road looked the same.

So with full speed I fell with
my car right into the river.

I broke with my chest
the steering wheel.

Probably broke a few ribs,
but at that time, who could--

who had time to look
into such things.

And the impact threw me to
the other side of the river.
It wasn't a big river.

But I hit with my
head the embankment.

Some people sitting in the back
of me were flying over my head.

I had in my pocket
a bottle of whiskey.

It flew out so far that
I could never find it.

So we left the poor
car in the river.

We grabbed ourself
and [? stoning ?]

and moaning and
groaning, we, on foot,

proceeded to the next
railroad station.

And it was the last Polish
train leaving the station.

The cars were splattered with
blood, because on-- a half

an hour earlier, a Stuka,
airplane, a German airplane,

a dive airplane had
made himself some fun

by flying low
alongside the windows

and shooting a couple of
the passengers inside.

The seats was
splattered with blood.

The windows were
full of bullet holes.
But it was at least a train.
I took this train.

And I came with this
train to Lemberg.

INTERVIEWER: Which was
then under Russian--

ERIC HOUSER: And then
on the Russian side--
in Lemberg, I met my wife.

But there was nothing
for me to do in Lemberg.

So I went to the Eastern oil
fields, which were Borysław.

INTERVIEWER: You had
left your family though?
ERIC HOUSER: Oh.
In Lemberg, my family stayed.

My father and my mother
both stayed in Lemberg.
Now the Russians came in.

My father was what is
called a vlasnyk an owner.

Now we employed
between 3 to 10 people.

And we hired out
help as necessary.

My father wasn't a
[INAUDIBLE] an owner.
He was a well-to-do man.

But this was-- this was
considered a tremendous crime.
And the Russians took us over.

For that matter,
anybody-- anyone

who had a barber shop
or a shoe repair shop
was an owner, suddenly.

And this was not only
a crime for the man.
It was a crime for his children.

According to Marxist
belief, your whole outlook,

your philosophy of life is
based on your economic basis.

So you are the son of
vlasnyk of an owner,

it means you are an owner
and is your children.

In a way, it becomes almost like
a {?_{?_[NON-ENGLISH SPEECH]._?}._?}
You are tainted for life.

I had-- I could do
nothing in Lemberg,
but everybody knew me anyhow.

So I went to Borysław
and we had some uncles,

uncles and aunts
living down there.

And nu-- excuse me--
and numerous family.

INTERVIEWER: That
was in 1939 then?

ERIC HOUSER: That
was in '30-- in '39.
And there I got a job.

Since I have a diploma
as an electrical engineer
and the Borysław power plant.

It was a beautiful power
plant, a beautiful power plant.

It would be even beautiful
by now, 40 years later, here
in the United States.

It wasn't as big as plants
in the United States,

but automated and
beautifully kept.

I became the head of the
mechanical and electrical
department.

It's-- to work for the Russians
is a peculiar experience.

The reason I do
this interview only,

I would like to show that the
Russians broke our spirit.
In a way, they're--

well, the Germans
killed us physically.

But in a way, the Russians
killed us mentally.
They broke our spirit.

They converted us from
normal human beings

who have some ambitions
of hope into ants

which go around all day
long and look for food.
And they have a special--

they have a special method
which they have perfected.

We all became like
Pavlovian dogs.
When you whistle, they salivate.
All day long one had to work.

The stores, where they give
you food, are open from eight
till four.
Now how can you do it?

If you have an old aunt at home,
an old parent, an old somebody,

a mother, but if
you have not-- like,
we are two working people.
My wife worked and I worked.
It was practically impossible.

Someone had to
continuously break the law.

You were not
permitted to go out.
But you had to.

So we continuously
smuggled ourselves out

to grab bread here and
a piece of meat here.

You-- then you grab
quickly a place in the line

to get a piece of leather
for a shoe sole and so on.

It became-- it was like
living in a prison.

While one, actually-- of
course, an American prison is--
compared to this, a holiday.

But it was living like
in a tremendous prison.

Everyone had to
work all day long.

At the same time,
fight for his food.

This is a great
invention of Stalin,

you know, that he was able
to get the people used to it.

That the most important
thing is work.

Food and all the other stuff you
will have to find for yourself.
Because we assume-- it's funny.

When the Israelis went
out to the desert,

when they came out from--
with Moses into the desert,

it says in the Bible, that
they revolt against him.
They cried, Zakharnu et HaDagim.

We remember the full flesh
pots and fish pots in Egypt.
And they revolt.

Stalin found out that he doesn't
have to give any fish pots
or flesh pots to his slaves.
You just have to give them work.

And somehow, they will be
able to muddle through.

But this muddling through
takes away half of your life.

Whenever you would have time
to think about something,
you're always--

you're always busy
with finding--
eh-- how to get by.

They threw us out
of our apartments.

In Russia, the law says that
you are permitted to have--

permitted-- that
you are entitled

to have six square
meters, which means
18 feet by 18 feet per person.
Two persons is 36 by 36.
But this doesn't mean--

first of all, they
don't let you take
your-- your furniture with you.

You leave everything
in your apartment
as you sit down there.

They let you take a
few eating utensils.

Because some-- some of
the secret Russian police

or some other officer
likes your apartment.

If he happen to see-- if
he happened not to see it,

if you can hide out,
you'll remain in there.

If somebody sees you,
they take it away.
So it's a continuous struggle.

And during this
continuous struggle,

they broke us so deeply
and so completely

that when Hitler later came,
he had it very easy with us.

The reason I'm saying it is
because Borysław was not a town

like all the other
stetls in Poland.
Borysław was an oil mining town.

All oil mining towns
are Klondike like,

as they call it here
in the United States.
The people are miners.
They are rough types.

They don't give a damn
about anybody there.
They carry weapons.
They carry knives there.

Eager to fight it out if
their heads [? drop. ?]
They're essentially not afraid.
But not after the Russian cure.

After the Russians went by,
they were all like lambs.

They were all beaten
down, dispirited.

And they went to their death
like a bunch of animals.
Well, we were there in Borysław.

I am-- I have to bring
out one special point.
The Russians were still with us.
They started-- of course, they--

they tried to make
informers out of everybody.

I was called in at
12 o'clock at night

and said you have to let us
know what your neighbors say.
I say I don't know.

I tried to talk
my way out of it.
I work all day.

Then I run to get
a piece of bread.
I don't know anything.
Doesn't matter.
You have to.

Besides, if you do, we
will treat you better.

You will get a better apartment,
and so on and so forth.
And many people fell for it.
And they watch you.
You have to report.

I didn't report, so they
called me in a few months later
and made me sign a paper.

You did not cooperate,
which-- which is a threat.

But they didn't last
too long, so the threat
did not materialize.

Let me illustrate
it by an example.

In the power plant
where I worked,

there was what is called
a condensation pump.

A condensation pump is a
unit, an auxiliary unit
at every turbine.
It was a beautiful power plant.

But this particularly
condensation pump

had a motor, which
was badly designed.

Every six or eight months,
the motor overheated.
We knew about it.

So when the motor started to
overheat, we had a spare part.
We put it in, and that was it.
The motor overheats.

I am called at 12
o'clock at night.

How come you did not report
to us that somebody's spraying
sand in the motor bearings?
I said nobody sprayed any sand.
It never happened before.

This motor regularly overheats
every six or eight months
the motor overheats.

And you have to put
in the spare part.
No, somebody sprayed sand on it.

And they gave me
such a bad time.

Somehow, I don't
know by what miracle

I was able to talk
my way out of this.
Because this meant Siberia.
At another time, they-- they--

Stalin had at that time a
helper whose name was Malenkov.

This Malenkov was supposed
to be Stalin's successor.

But later on, when Stalin
died, they threw him out.
Malenkov issued a new law.

Kto ne raboet, tot ne
kushaet means who--

the one who doesn't
work doesn't eat.
It was taken literally.

Many old people, many retired
people committed suicide.

You could see the old
people also standing

outside selling
their last shirt.

A man was selling a
pair of eyeglasses.

One guy was selling a shirt
which was only one sleeve.

I mean, anything to
get a piece of bread.
And he issued another law.

You have to be
punctually at your job.

If you're five minutes
late, you get arrested.

If you're 15 minutes late, you
can get what they call detskiy
srok five years in Siberia.
It means a child's--

a child's-- what does
srok mean in English--

a child's verdict-- a childish
verdict, a very easy verdict,
five years in Siberia.

So one of those
days, I am at job.

And I see that one of my
machinists is not there.
The clock is striking eight.
He is not there.

The clock is striking
8:05 and he is not there.
So I ran down to the time clock.
I risked my own life.

I pulled out his card
and I shoved it in,
making believe that he is there.

Because later on the
police came around,
checking if everybody is there.
His card was in the right spot.
He came in 30 minutes later.
He had a bad accident.
The guy was half crazy.

He was trying to repair an
old motorcycle, which he had.

And he fell down and
broke his head and so on.

He came in perplexed
and bewildered,

because he knew what
was waiting for him.

This same guy helped
me later to escape
during one of the pogroms.
He remembered.

Well, here we are now
with the Russians.
Time is going by.
And there is May 1941.
Now every-- the Polish--

there was a sizable Polish
population in the town
of Borysław.
And they had children.

Their children went to
the local high school.

There is a Polish holiday,
which is called the holiday
of the third of May.

It's just some-- something
to do with Polish history.

Anyhow, wherever Poles
as a group are living,

on the third of May
the children usually

dress in the national
costumes and sing songs
and dance national dances.
And it's sort of a celebration.

And this has been going
on since the year,
I believe, 1820 or so on.
So it was, of course, forbidden.

Now this part of previous
Poland had became Ukraine.

And the Russians had
forbidden any Polish national.
But children are like children.

How do you reason with
12, 14, 15-year-old?
They have to have their holiday.

So naturally, they
came in on the 3rd

of May dressed in these
costumes, sang the polkas,
danced around.

And naturally, there
was an informer.
There is an informer.

Where there are
three people, there
must be two informers in Russia.

And this informer
informed to them.

And the children were
arrested the same night.

As they took the
children away, they

commandeered company
trucks to load them.

I believe there were 212, or
220, between the ages 12 to 16.

They took them away
in these trucks.
They were three or four trucks.
I don't know how many.

Some of these truck
drivers were Jewish.
It is said--

I didn't hear it as
my own eye-- ears,

but it was said that one of the
truck drivers, a Jewish truck
driver laughed and made jokes.
Poland is finished.
It will never be there again.

And laughed their
head off-- his head

off when the
children were loaded.

And the parents were
naturally crying.
The Germans struck in June 1941.

The Russian army-- excuse
me-- which up to that day

had strutted around, we are
invincible [? singing ?] ran.
They ran.

They left all their heavy
equipment, and they ran.

The parents of-- and
they-- they were not--

there was a period
of six or eight

hours that there
was neither Russians
nor Germans in the town.

The Germans hadn't arrived
yet, their patrols,
and the Russians have gone.

The parents of the
arrested children

naturally run to the prison to
get-- to find their children.
There were no children.

But in the prison yard,
there was a shallow grave.

They uncover it, and there
were all these children killed,

all of them killed with a
single shot in the head.

Some of them had their
hands tied with barbed wire.

That's a special
Russian invention.
I don't know why they do it.

You-- you also must realize how
executions are done in Russia.

There's-- there's a
tiny little cell--

we saw it here when we
broke the prison open.

And in this cell,
there is a door.

In this door is an
opening and they

had to-- at the height
of a human head.

They tied the poor
victims to the door,

and the executioner shoots him
so that the prisoner doesn't
know who has done it.

A family shouldn't
be able to say,
in heaven, who has killed him.

Normally, executions
are done by firing--

you know, where a man stands
in front of the firing squad.
The Russians have their own way.

Anyhow, the-- all these
children were killed.

And the parents
suddenly remembered

that this Jew made a snide
remark when they loaded.

And a cry went out all
over the city of Warsaw,

the Jews have
killed our children.

And the Ukrainians, who were
Jew haters to begin with,
united with the Polish parents.
And they all run around.

They rounded up the
families of those truck

drivers and all Jews to
whom they can [INAUDIBLE]..

And of course, there
were robbers and looters,

the intelligentsia, the
better known people.

And they killed them
in the most brutal way.

First they had to crawl on their
knees to kiss their dead bodies
and beg their forgiveness.

And then they were
beaten to death
with lead pipes and iron pipes.

A few people survived
because there

were a few Ukrainians,
decent people,

who had friends among
those who were rounded up.

They went into the melee and
pulled them physically out.
An Ukrainian could go out.
They pulled out the rabbi.
I don't know.

Some Ukrainian went in
and pulled out the rabbi.

Another Ukrainian went in and
pulled out one of my friends.
Bauer-- his name was Bauer.
And so on-- but--

most of-- I lost 30 people of
close family in that night.

I myself escaped by
the breath of a hair.
I-- I went in.
My family was there.
I told them disperse.

There is something
vicious going on.
They said no.
We sit together.

We feel better when
we sit together.
So they sat together.
And they all died together.
I ran away and I hid out.

Anyhow, the Germans
occupied our town.

As soon as the Germans occupied
our town, Jews had to register.

I registered as an engineer,
as a technical man.
INTERVIEWER: Hold it up--
ERIC HOUSER: And I was given--

INTERVIEWER: Hold it
up for the camera.
ERIC HOUSER: I was given this.

And of course, later on,
all kinds of classifications

were again given
and again given.

Because they had to
decrease the number
of the Jewish population.

The town of Borysław, there
was 16 or 18,000 Jewish people.

And at that time, the Jewish
population was falling.

Because there was all
kinds of little towns.

Well, Borysław was considered
a town of middle size,
a major Jewish settlement.

Sometimes, we even had the
Jewish mayor down there.

So they crowded all
these Jewish inhabitants
of all the other settlements.

And I estimated there were
approximately 20 to 25,000

people dispersed through
the ghetto of Borysław.
INTERVIEWER: When --

ERIC HOUSER: And next to
Borysław was Drohobycz,
[? sister ?] town.

INTERVIEWER: When was,
you know, the ghetto
formally established?

ERIC HOUSER: In 1941, and the
Germans came in immediately,
oh, maybe a week later.
INTERVIEWER: I see.

ERIC HOUSER: We were
told to leave our places.

Of course, one
could bribe his way.

So they let us still
live for a month or two

in the [? period. ?] But
essentially, one had to go.
The ghetto was established.

And the Jewish people have to
live in this designed area.

And then, of course, they
kept decreasing the ghetto
all the time.

Let's say every two or three
months there was a selection

called Judenaktion, an
action against the Jews.

During this selection, everyone
who was not considered worthy
of living was killed.

Women were extremely
in danger-- children--
extremely in danger.

I saw myself some women who
had identification stating

that they were working people
tear up the identification

and go to death
with their children.

And I also saw some
women who voluntarily

brought their children
to the collecting place
and left them there.
Because numbers were important.

The-- the Germans created
a council of elders.

The president of the
Council of Elders

was a Jewish soldier from First
World War by the name of Hertz.
And he was there.

And he was given the task
of delivering the victims.
He organized the Jewish militia.

This Jewish militia was
given the task of bringing
in, let's say, 2,000 people.

This all was done
with the active--

not [? fair-- ?] under the
operation of the German police,
which was called Schutzpolizei.

The Schutzpolizei had
mounted the detachment
which was called Reiterpolizei.

And of course, there was the
Ukrainian auxiliary police,
the Ukrainian militia.

All these police forces
were there for one purpose,
to round up the Jews.

It's a funny things how
these Germans operate.

For instance, at what
time they issued an order.

When they made us
leave our houses,
the [? loot ?] was there.
Nobody could go in.
I left the house.
But I had left some books.

In my craziness, I carried
books with me around.

And I went back down
there to get a book.

I saw something
moving in a corner.

An old Polish farmer had
broken into the house

and had stolen the
door of a furnace.

You know, there were
these old type furnaces

which opened so far,
they had cast iron doors.

These cast iron
doors were valuable.
You couldn't buy them so easily.

So this poor old
soul had stolen it.
And he had it.
And he has hidden in a corner.

I didn't know if he had some
bad intentions toward me.
Who could know?

So a German policeman
was walking by.
I had this with me.
So I called him.

And I told him, Mr. Policeman,
somebody broke in down there,
I don't know what to do.
He went in.

Pulled the old guy by
the ear out to the window

and shot him right in
the head for a piece
of a door, an old door.
And this went on for a while.

INTERVIEWER: Can I
stop you for a second?

Now prior to the Germans
coming to Borysław,

you were living with your
wife, apart from your immediate
family.

Did you have any contact with
them at all, with your parents,
with your sisters--
ERIC HOUSER: I wrote a few --
INTERVIEWER: --and brothers?
ERIC HOUSER: --letters to them.

INTERVIEWER: Did you have
any idea what was happening--

ERIC HOUSER: I wrote
a few letters to them
and my sister answered.

I even made some attempts
to bring them to Borysław.

I bribed some truck driver
who was going for the Germans

to Lwów to bring
back some parts.
But I was unsuccessful.
I tried.
But, no.
Now--

INTERVIEWER: You should
also explain what this is.

ERIC HOUSER: The Germans
kept decreasing our number.

And finally, only one word,
R, which means Rüstung.
R means Rüstung, armament.

And anyone who had armament
had to have such an ID, which
looks like this.

INTERVIEWER: This meant that
you worked in the armaments?

ERIC HOUSER: R for
the armament, for
armament connected industries--

and uh, of course, one had
to issue a little bribe.

This wasn't as
simple that we had

some silverware hidden
outside from my uncle.

Which, while I was entitled
to it, if anybody was entitled
to it, I was entitled to it.

And-- but the bribe had to
be given, because who cared?
So I had to bribe the--

the Jewish council got
very much demoralized.

In the beginning, they
started out as real helpers--
helpers.

They decided that the
old people should die
so that the young [could live].
[COUGHS] But--

INTERVIEWER: Were you involved
at all with the Jewish council?

ERIC HOUSER: I-- not very
much-- once they called me in.

Since I am an engineer from
a German technical school

and I speak perfect
German, I was called in.
The Germans are peculiar people.

While they addressed
everybody "Du Jude,"

since I am an
engineer, they called
me Herr Engineer, Mr. Engineer.

So the chief of the
police called me in

and said Mr. Engineer,
I have decided

that you will become the
head of the Jewish council.
That was a big honor.

And there was-- and there was
a pot of gold in it, because--
but I didn't want it.

So I said please,
Herr Commandant,

let me think about
it for a moment.
And I smuggled myself out.
And I ran away.
And I hid out for three weeks.

I lay in a basement up
to my knees in water.
My wife was also there.

In the meantime, they
nominated another one.

In this way I escaped
of this dubious honor.

Now the people had
a difficult task.

Because they kept saying, if
we will not supply the victims,

the Germans will come in and
take away all the victims.

Of course, who can
[? aggregate ?] themselves

the power to say
you should live?
But it was done, anyhow.
So this went on for some time.

I would like to describe to
you now all these things which
I am telling you.

Most of them I saw
with my own eyes.
Many I did not.
I know it from witnesses.
There was-- there was one guy.
His name was Max Hendler.

This Max Hendler was
our Verbindungsmann,

which means our connection
to the German police.

The Jewish council
had nominated him

to be the connecting link
between the Jewish council
and the German police.
He was an extremely decent man.
[COUGHS]

He felt, apparently, that I will
remember [all these things].

And he, as our connector
to the German police,

saw most of these things
with his own eyes.
He had to be there.
And he told them to me.

Because in the morning, he
went to the police to get from
there-- there--

they ordered cognac,
vodka, women, I don't know,

gold, silver, rocks,
which he had to bring over
to the Jewish people.

The Jewish people then tried to
make a collection among all us

who [INAUDIBLE] had
something left to--

to-- of course, they collected
more than they needed.

Later on, they collected a
little bit for themselves.

And it had to be carried
to the German police.

In the afternoon, since he also
had this R and the same thing,

he had to be at his working
place, which was next to me.
He sat right next to me.

And he came in, and he
told me how it happened.

They had brought in a
group for execution.

So they were brought to a
village called Tustanowice.
That's a village close Borysław.

The Jews had
previously to deliver

a detachment of forced
labor to dig a big grave.
Over this grave a plank--

it was an opening, I
would say, three meters,

which is three times three,
10, 11 feet deep by something
like this, by something--

by 20 feet or 30 feet wide
over this plank was laid.

The people brought
into execution

had to undress
completely to their skin.

And they were very
rough with them.

The women, even the last
moment they were ashamed.

They tore off their--
their clothes.

They examined them in
the most brutal way,

if they had hidden somewhere
a piece of gold or something.

He told me that some women
clutched a picture of her child
or something.

They tore them off their
hand, or a [INAUDIBLE]

showing Magen
David or something.

And they all had to
march to this plank.

At this plank stood the
German policeman [? Mittas ?]..

He was one of the
Schutzpolizei. [? Mittas ?] was,

in private life, a
forester and a hunter
for the Count of Lichtenburg.

He was a professional hunter,
a very good sharpshooter.

And he did this with
zeal and enthusiasm.

And he shot every victim
in the back of his head.

Well, after a while, if
you shoot two, three, four,
500 people.
You get tired.
So his hand wavered.
He missed.

So people half dead
fell into the grave.

Children were sometimes
thrown in alive.

Two Jewish men who were
naked decided to run.
They made a run for it.

But the German mounted
police gave chase.

They caught them, trampled
them with their horses

till they were
whimpering [? messes-- ?]
they were still alive--

and threw these whimpering
[? messes ?] into the grave.

In the grave sits an Ukrainian
militiaman who staples--
puts one body on the other.

Because space is at
premium, after all.
We have to hide to--

we have to cover three,
four, five, 600, 800 people,
something, thousand people.

Space becomes quite-- so
they had to be squeezed in,
one close to each other.

And then they shoveled
the grave over.

Of course, many people,
as I said, are half dead.

So they fight
against suffocation.

The Germans don't make
a secret out of it.

So the Poles and the Ukrainians
who walk by [into the fields]
say that the earth is rumbling.

And I am told the earth
sometimes rumbled--

the earth sometimes
rumbled for two,

three hours till
it's quieted down.

And that was one of
the-- one of the--

at another time, this is also
a very characteristic time.

There is a Judenaktion,
an action against Jews.
They fall into the--

and they fall into all
the-- in the ghetto.

There was a time-- a time still
a small ghetto in the ghetto.
And they fall in the camp.

And they tried to find
out those guys who
didn't have [INAUDIBLE] signs.

And sometimes, if they have
to fulfill their quota,

the Jewish police
will tear up the sign,

throw it away, and
take the guy anyhow.
[MACHINERY NOISE]

A Jewish drill master, I
believe his name was Hartmann.

I think his name was Hartmann
jumps out of the window.
The windows were low.
It was inside the camp.
He jumps out, tries to run.

He fell and broke his leg,
or otherwise injured himself.
He couldn't move.
He lives down there moaning.

It's characteristic, the--
the Germans were short-handed.

They didn't-- so there were some
young Germans down there from

their families who all
belonged to the Hitler Youth,

Hitlerjugend, and also
young German girls.
They helped.

Die helfen aus, it's
called in German.
They helped out.
So they helped.

They stood there and helped
to surround and round up
these Jews.

So this officer goes and gives
such a youngster a pistol
and says finish this Jew.

The Jew was laying
on the "Leg ihn um!"

Leg ihn um in German
means tip him over.

It's a slang word for
kill him, Leg ihn um.
But the kid was only a kid.
He was maybe 12 or 13-years-old.

No matter how-- you know,
for a kid, it-- it suddenly--
he shuddered.
He was afraid uh --

so the other SS man, who stood
near say "Lass den Jungen zu
Ruhe," leave the kid in peace.
The kid is afraid.

"Soll er lernen,"
cried the first one.
He should learn.
Now that is something.
He should learn.

He should learn how to
kill defenseless people--
learning, you know?

"Soll er lernen," it
sounds in my ears.

At another time, a
Jewish drill master--

drilling is a very
dangerous job.
Particularly the way it is done.
It's dangerous, even right now.

But drilling for
oil particularly
is a dangerous job.

One handles heavy loads and
heavy pieces of equipment.

A Jewish drill master had a
heavy drill, a six inch drill,

a six inch drill weighs two or
3,000 pounds, fall on his feet,
and crush his foot.
They took him to the hospital.

When the German policeman,
by the name of [? Nemeth ?]

I believe he was,
found out that there's

a crippled Jew in the hospital,
he drove to the hospital.

Has him carried
out to [the lawn]

and shot him in the head right
in front of all the people.

A wounded Jew was
no good to them.
He couldn't do any work anymore.

These atrocities went
on day and night.

They also transferred itself
to the local population.

The local population saw
what's being done against us.

And it's being done by
the legal authorities.

So they kind of assumed
that that's all right to do.

And everybody likes
the idea of being
better off than [INAUDIBLE].

Somebody is-- some
famous Russian author

has written an interesting
novel about this.

And he says Hitler
built, like, a ladder.

On top of it were the
Germans, the Aryans.
They're just the top of it.

Below [INAUDIBLE] were the
French, and so on and so forth,

the English, the
Polish Ukrainians.

On the list, below the last
line, there were the Jews.

And everybody who was
a few ranks higher

feel better about it
because there was still
somebody who fel--
who was lower.

And this somehow creates
a special psychosis.

It makes people
cruel towards people.

Because they begin to feel
we are the better ones.

Like Hitler said, what do you
worry about killing a Jew?

You never worry about killing
a cockroach or something.
I mean, you just step on it.

Who worries about
killing a cockroach?
I saw this.
I saw this with my own eyes.
Hm.
[COUGHS]
I was hidden on a roof.
It was one of the Judenaktionen.

Naturally, when
there was an action,

although we had all the
papers, we tried to stay out.

We tried to stay out
of the mainstream.

Because, as I said, if the
Jewish militia couldn't fulfill

their number, [INAUDIBLE] threat
exactly if you don't bring in--

if you bring in only 1,999 in
2,000, you're the 2,000th man.

Instead of him being,
he would have taken me.
So I'd better stayed out.
So I was hiding out.
There was a hole.

And I saw, as they let
out the orphans, we had--

many-- many people
died out of starvation.
I was young and strong.
I could run better.
I was smart.

I could somehow manage to
barter something to steal some
[INAUDIBLE] piece of bread, to--
I somehow could help myself.
But many people couldn't.
So they died.
They had children.

And the Jewish council
created a orphanage
where these children were kept.

For a while, I was head
of a Jewish workshop.

And I had 40 or
42,000 machinists.

And we were given
scraps of metal.

And out of these
scraps of metal,

we made shovels for
the German army.

We could steal a few
shovels and barter them

with the local
peasants for bread.

And also because we
were working people,
we get our rations [INAUDIBLE].

It was an ounce of bread,
daily, an ounce of bread

and a bowl of soup made out of
bones of horse meat and so on
and [INAUDIBLE].

Out of this ounce of bread, my
workers cut off a tiny crumb
and gave it to the orphanage.

But finally, the order came
to liquidate the orphanage.

The children were
afraid, and they cried.

They wouldn't go
out into the yard.

So the head nurse
sacrificed herself.

The head nurse had
all these papers.
She could have stayed alive.
But the children cried.

So she walked in front of
them, and they followed her.

One of these children was
a little blonde eyed--

I see him in front of my eyes,
a little guy with blond hair
and blue eyes.

He was, maybe, [COUGHS]
four or five years old.

But the-- the Jewish mothers had
indoctrinated their children.
If you can run, run.
He ran.

There was one German
in front of the column.

He couldn't leave the column
to run after this one child,

because the whole column
would have dispersed.
So he-- he lets it go.

A Polish woman saw the--
saw this little child.
She grabbed him by the arm.

She dragged him back and
brought him to the German.

Not only did she drag him
back, she laughed and said
they will give you candy.
[COUGHS]

Well, this
brutalization was going
on all the time, all the time.

I saw a Jewish militiaman
bringing his own mother
to the collecting point.

There was a collecting
point, a previous cinema,

where they collected the
prisoners before they delivered

them to the Germans,
who either shipped them

by railroad to
annihilation places
or shot them in Tustanowice.
And-- they--
I-- when this happened--

oh, I wanted to-- oh,
[INAUDIBLE] sorry it is--

I wanted to tell about this
bru-- the total brutalization.

This Jewish militiamen
brought in his own mother.
I knew him.

He was-- he was a man who
worked in the oil fields.

In an oil field, an engineer is
sort of a distinguished person.

They all always addressed
me Mr. Engineer.
[TELEPHONE RINGING]

They showed me some
sort of respect.
I looked at him.

He was bringing
in his own mother.
He said, what can I do?

I have to bring in a
certain number of people.

If I don't bring
it-- her in today,
they will bring-- take me.

And they will grab
her in tomorrow.
So I'm bringing her in today.

One quite often
had to bribe those,
uh, those Jewish militiamen.
I remember one particular scene.

By nowadays standards,
it's nothing unusual.
But I don't know.
There-- there was the barracks.

They're divided in a female
part and a male part.

And I tried to walk
out of it there--
but there was only one exit.

There was a nice, good looking,
young Jewish woman walking.
And this militiaman came along.
He grabs her.

Throws her on a
bunch of rags which

were laying next to the door
and starts having sex with her.
Nobody could walk by.

Because they-- the door,
there was only one door,

and they were just laying
right in front of the door.
After a while, he got up.
I looked at him.

And again, he said to me, Mr.
Engineer, I am protecting her.
He felt he's in his own rights.
I am looking the other side.

She has no papers
when she is around.
I am protecting her.
She owes me.

Besides we both will die
tomorrow anyhow, or a day

after tomorrow, so what's
the big difference?

Well, these people, the
German police, whom I said--

the Schutzpolizei, some of
their names, which I remember,

like
{?_Mittas,_{?_Mittas,_[INAUDIBLE NAMES]_?}_?}

their captain was
called Wippert.

Wippert was a specially vicious
man, especially vicious man.

Again, if he had to
deliberate 1,800 people,

he would collect 2,000,
2,500, and starts

to bargain, you know,
and collect gold

from the people who he let go,
because he only had to go--

besides he took great pride
that instead of 2,000,
he delivered 2,200.

One scene, which was told
to me by Max Hendler,

is Wippert had collected-- they
had collected all these people

and brought them to
the collecting point.

And there was a
hunchback among them.

Of course, this was a terrific
[? guy, ?] a hunchback.

But this hunchback was
apparently quite wealthy.
And he had managed to survive.
The hunchback was there.

Wippert came in to
inspect his catch.
And the hunchback, who had--
I forgot his name--

who had some money hidden
somewhere, or some valuables,
[INAUDIBLE] said "Mister --

Captain Wippert, I have some
gold and pearls and so on
hidden somewhere.

If you let me go, I
will let you have."
And Wippert started to beat him.
A hunchback wants to be alive.
He beats him.
He threw him to the floor.

And he wore spurs, at
that time, on his boots.

And with his spurs, he
[? riddled ?] his face.
And everybody was laughing.

The Germans were
laughing their head off.
A hunchback wants to be alive.

A hunchback has no right
to be alive, does he?
They kept decreasing this--
this camp all the time.
And uh, we were down there.
We built a big tunnel.

I have built a big tunnel
from the camp to the outside
under the fence.

I delivered a child
from this camp.

A child was born in
this camp, and it would
have been killed right away.
I delivered it to the fence.

And it is alive right
now somewhere in Israel.
[COUGHS]

INTERVIEWER: How was that
kind of thing possible,

you know, without the
detection of the Germans, and--

ERIC HOUSER: They looked
away, the other side.
We didn't think about it.

There was-- there were
not so many people.

Don't you [? forget, ?]
this was 1943.

Stalingrad had eaten up
most of the German forces.

Anyone who could carry a
rifle was at Stalingrad.

The Ukrainian militia,
they sometimes
would have done something.
They didn't care.
And it was sheer luck.
It was sheer luck.

We were just alive
by a string of--
of lucky coincidences.

At one time, this I have
to describe-- there was
a Judenaktion against the Jews.

The camp wasn't yet--
fully established yet.

They [? [ran from
home to home] ?]

and they rounded up Jews
who didn't have papers,

who didn't have professions and
so on, they just rounded them
up.
Now I found out about it.

I was work-- I was going to
work with my wife in a column.
I found out about it.

And there was no
place for her to hide.
I knew a Jewish militiaman.

He used to be a drilling
master on one of my oil
wells or some-- but I knew him.
He knew me.
So I knew where he lived.

So I took my wife and
went to his house.
He went to his house.

And I said to him, you
know what's going on?
He said I know what's going on.
I cannot help you.

I have hidden my wife
among some Poles.
I had no place to go.

So I said let me stay
in your apartment.

He said, OK, stay
in my apartment.
He locked the apartment.
He gave me the key.
And he went away.

I hear that they are
breaking in all the doors
in the neighboring apartments.

In the last moment,
I had an idea.

I throwed out a piece
of paper somewhere

from a book or something
and scribbled on it.

The name-- the owner
of this apartment

is Mr. Kalt. Mr.
Kalt is a militiaman
with the Jewish militia.
He is in service.
"Ich bin im Dienst."
German.

And I pulled out a
pin from somewhere,

and I nailed it to the
outside of the door.
And I locked the door.

A few seconds later, the German,
"Oh," sagt, "Der Mann ist
im Dienst."
The man is in service.
And he left without breaking in.
That's the reason I'm alive.

They also-- the-- this
fellow [? Mittas ?]

from the police, whose
name I mentioned so often,

kills also an awful
lot of other people.

There were quite a
few Russian prisoners

of war working in the
fields and in the oil fields

and working around all the
industrial establishment.

And there was a group
of women soldiers.
They had a-- a fem--

[CLEARS THROAT] a woman
captain was there.

And one of those
days, uh, they were

ordered to carry munitions from
one railroad car to the other.

And the woman captain rounded
up the soldiers and said,

we are not going
to carry ammunition
to kill our brothers.

So they killed them
all right there.
Now--

INTERVIEWER: You and
your wife were together
during this entire period?

ERIC HOUSER: Sometimes--
sometimes she

was in the female part and
I was in the male part.

But later on-- oh,
as we built up--

as we built up this department
of Beskidenerdoel, this,
which I didn't say--

the oil wells were
finally taken over

by a company called
Beskidenerdoel,

which means crude oil
of the Beskid Mountains.
This Beskidenerdoel was, uh--

the man who had it was a
man by the name of Beitz.

He was given the title
of the Righteous One
from the Yad Vashem.

I am not so sure that he
is the one who deserves it.
But he was given.

He supposedly-- he supposedly,
by his actions, saved,
they say, some 2,000 Jews.

When we counted ourselves after
the war, there were only 200
of us alive.

Well, anyhow-- so I
worked for this Beskiden.

And being an engineer,
I got a little,

uh, I know, 10 by 10 chamber,
which was in the camp
where I could live with my wife.

They told us when-- and they
assigned us to office work.

When they assigned
us to office work,

they told us you
have to be every day,
every day shaved and washed.

Of course, nobody gave
us any soap or anything.

But we were lucky, because in
Borysław is a source of natural
gas.

And most of these
buildings had natural gas
piped into the building.

So warm water was
always available.

That's the way we could
keep ourselves clean.

People who didn't
keep themselves clean
were doomed to death.

They either died of typhoid or
fever or were shot by the Ger--
